title: ISic030197. ISic030197
body:
Facsimile Images

a
|a 1[---]ΦΑΥΛΛΟ[.---]\(([---..]ΑΤΡΑ))/
2((.ΔΔΔΔ´sign_uninterpreted))
b
|b 1[---]ΣΜΑΤΡΟ
2\((ΔΟ̄ΡΟ̄))/
3((ͰΕΝΑΤΑ))

l.1 φράτρα del | l.2 δο̄́ρο̄ del

Apparatus criticus

  • Text after Cordano 1992

English translation

Italian translation

commentary

This document is one of a large deposit (c. 150) of lead tesserae found in a storeroom of Athena's sanctuary at the archaeological site of Kamarina. The lamina appears to be used twice (see Cordano 1992, pp. 53-54). To the first use would correspond the text Φάυλλο[ς on face a, ͱενάτα on face b. The second use is associated with the text .ΔΔΔΔ sign_uninterpreted | φρ]άτρα on face a and the text Ματρο|δο̄́ρο̄ on face b. In the second use, face a is used as face b and vice versa, and the writing is upside down on both faces if compared to the first use. The first engraving, the one related to the first use, uses smaller letters than the second one. Moreover, the first text has not been erased in order to engrave the second, therefore it is clearly visible. The uninterpreted sign after the numeral on face a could be, according to Cordano 1992 (p. 54-55), a specific marker. See also ISic030200. For a similar reuse of the tessera, within the same fratra, see also ISic030198.

bibliography

  • Cordano 1992 70 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002437
  • 42.0846 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10000796
  • 52.0920 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10000796
  • 54.0892 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10000796

commentary

This document is one of a large deposit (c. 150) of lead tesserae found in a storeroom of Athena's sanctuary at the archaeological site of Kamarina. The lamina appears to be used twice (see Cordano 1992, pp. 53-54). To the first use would correspond the text Φάυλλο[ς on face a, ͱενάτα on face b. The second use is associated with the text .ΔΔΔΔ sign_uninterpreted | φρ]άτρα on face a and the text Ματρο|δο̄́ρο̄ on face b. In the second use, face a is used as face b and vice versa, and the writing is upside down on both faces if compared to the first use. The first engraving, the one related to the first use, uses smaller letters than the second one. Moreover, the first text has not been erased in order to engrave the second, therefore it is clearly visible. The uninterpreted sign after the numeral on face a could be, according to Cordano 1992 (p. 54-55), a specific marker. See also ISic030200.
